Fast Log-Gaussian Point-Process Methods for Grid Cells

lgcpspatial.estimators module

lgcpspatial.estimators.estimate_period_via_autocorrelation(N, K, mask, res=5)[source]

Estimate grid period using autocorrelation

Parameters:

  • N (2D np.array) – Number of visits to each location

  • K (2D np.array) – Number of spikes observed at each location

  • mask (L×L 2D np.array) – boolean mask for “in bounds” regions to analyze

  • res (int) – small positive integer; Upsampling resolution; default is 5x

Returns:

  • P (positive float) – Estimated grid period in pixels

  • Δs (1D np.array) – Bin separations for upsampled radial autocorrelation

  • acup (1D np.array) – Upsampled radial autocorrelation

  • acorr2 (L×L 2D np.array) – 2D autocorrelogram

lgcpspatial.estimators.biased_rate(N, K, rho=0.9, gamma=0.5, alpha=None)[source]

Regularized per-bin rate estimate. This divides the spike count by the number of visits, with a small regularization parameter to prevent division by zero.

This estimator is not very good, and you shouldn’t use it; It’s provided as a straw-man to show how much better the other estimators are.

Parameters:

  • N (2D np.array) – Number of visits to each location

  • K (2D np.array) – Number of spikes observed at each location

  • rho (float) – Regularization: small parameter to add to N to avoid ÷0

  • gamma (float) – Bias parameter; defaults to 0.5

Returns:

2D array

Return type:

Regularized (biased) estimate of firing rate in each bin

lgcpspatial.estimators.kde(N, K, sigma, mask=None, **kwargs)[source]

Estimate rate using Gaussian KDE smoothing. This is better than estimating the rate using a binned histogram, but worse than a Gaussian-Process estimator.

Parameters:

  • N (2D np.array) – Number of visits to each location

  • K (2D np.array) – Number of spikes observed at each location

  • sigma (float) – kernel radius exp(-x²/sigma) (standard deviation in x and y ×⎷2)

Returns:

2D array

Return type:

KDE rate estimate of firing rate in each bin

lgcpspatial.estimators.linearGP(N, K, sigma, mask, tol=0.0001, reg=1e-05)[source]

Linear Gaussian process rate map. This is a linear (not log-linear) model.

Error are approximated. The average firing rate of the cell is calculated, and the per-timepoint measurement error is assumed to equal this. Multiple visits to the same location improve reduce measurement error proportionaly.

It is not recommended for inferring firing-rate maps, but it is a fast example of GP inference on a 2D arena which may be instructive.

This uses the Minimum residual solver, which is fast, and only requires a function which can compute Hessian- vector products. This can be done quickly with circulant (convolutional) covariance priors using the FFT.

Parameters:

  • N (2D np.array) – Number of visits to each location

  • K (2D np.array) – Number of spikes observed at each location

  • sigma (float) – kernel radius exp(-x²/sigma) (standard deviation in x and y ×⎷2)

Returns:

  • rate (2D np.array) – GP rate estimate of firing rate in each bin

  • kern (2D np.array) – Prior covariance kernel used for inference

  • y (2D np.array) – Binned rates (K/N) used as observations

lgcpspatial.estimators.convolutionalLinearGP(N, K, sigma, mask, pad=None, tol=0.0001, reg=1e-05)[source]

Special case of a linear Gaussian process (see linearGP) which can be calculated extremely quickly.

This is not recommended for inferring firing rate maps, but rather to provide an instructive example of how GP inference relates to simpler KDE smoothers.

This assumes that the measurement error is spatially uniform. This is assumption is wrong, but the computational simpicity and connection to the KDE estimate are instructive.

Parameters:

  • np.array) (K (2D) –

  • np.array) –

  • (float) (sigma) –

Returns:

  • λcnv (2D np.array) (GP rate estimate of firing rate in each bin)

  • gft (2D np.array) (Fourier transform of computed convolution kernel)
